content.webTitle: Morning mail: Liberals preselect Sharma to contest Turnbull's old seat

fields.headline: Morning mail: Liberals preselect Sharma to contest Turnbull's old seat
fields.bodyText: Good morning, this is Richard Parkin bringing you the main stories and must-reads on Friday 14 September. Top stories The Liberal party has picked Dave Sharma to stand in Wentworth, the seat vacated by Malcolm Turnbull’s resignation from parliament. Sharma – a former ambassador to Israel – beat seven other Liberal candidates in a marathon meeting that finished at 1.30am on Friday. Sharma defeated high-profile women, including Scott Morrison’s pick for the job, Katherine O’Regan. She was originally tipped to get the Liberal party nod after the frontrunner Andrew Bragg withdrew from the contest under mounting pressure from Canberra. Sharma will now face a tough byelection battle in October, with early polling indicating a big swing against the Liberals, who have never lost the seat. Whether the seat remains in Liberal hands may hinge on whether a high-profile independent, former AMA head Dr Kerryn Phelps now runs. Australia will miss its Paris climate targets as carbon emissions continue to soar, new data shows. The figures from NDEVR Environmental for the year up to June 2018 show that Australia will miss its Paris targets by around a billion tonnes of carbon dioxide if emissions continue on their current trajectory. It is the third consecutive year for record-breaking emissions. Excluding land use, the emissions will tally 558m tonnes, the highest since records began in 2002. “The data’s telling us clearly again that we’re not on a trajectory to meet our targets,” said NDEVR’s Matt Drum, “there’s no effective policy to meet our targets, but we’re still hearing commentary from the government that we’re on track to meet our targets.” Donald Trump has made the extraordinary and demonstrably false claim that 3,000 people did not die in Puerto Rico as a result of Hurricane Maria, asserting in a tweet that the figure was dramatically increased by the Democrats “in order to make me look as bad as possible”. The official death toll from the Puerto Rican government was adjusted upwards, but following the release of a report from the George Washington University report that suggested the number of excess deaths was in the range of 2,658 to 3,290, not 64 as they had been reporting earlier. The mayor of San Juan, Carmen Yulín Cruz, condemned Trump’s tweet, saying it showed an “appalling” lack of respect, and concluding: “Simply put: delusional, paranoid, and unhinged from any sense of reality. Trump is so vain he thinks this is about him. NO IT IS NOT.” Billionaire Westfield founder Frank Lowy has used the annual address at the Lowy Institute to heavily condemn Australia’s public discourse on immigration, the 87-year-old urging the nation to adopt “an ambitious migration program”. One of Australia’s best-known migrant stories, Lowy fled Nazi persecution as a child, before arriving in Australia in 1952 via Palestine and Israel. “I have … been disturbed by the negative tone of the debate over immigration,” said Lowy. “There is a rising crescendo of opinion from columnists and politicians, saying we should reduce our immigration intake”, he said, warning that the nation should not forget the “opportunities of immigration” while becoming fixated with perceived problems. France has warned that a no-deal Brexit could see trains and planes from the UK stopped, with the French minister for European affairs suggesting emergency legislation could be passed to protect its citizens. France is pushing for key negotiating issues to be resolved before a mooted 29 March, 2019 exit, rather than a “blindfold Brexit”. The governor of the Bank of England, Mark Carney, also warned the British cabinet on Thursday that the impact of a no-deal Brexit could be as catastrophic as the GFC in 2008, with unemployment reaching double figures and house prices falling by 25-35% over three years. Nearly two in every five women in the world who kill themselves are Indian, a Lancet study has found this week. With one-fifth of Indian women still marrying before the age of 15, experts blame the cultural practice of early marriage, as well as male violence against women, as strong contributing factors. “Our social norms are very regressive,” said public health director Poonam Muttreja. “In the village, a girl is called her father’s daughter, then she is her husband’s wife, and when she has a son, she is her son’s mother.” The researchers say the evidence presented amount to a “public health crisis” in the world’s second-most populous nation. Sport It could be a case of “third time’s a treat” for the Greater Western Sydney Giants, as they face Collingwood in the AFL semi-final this weekend, where despite their tender years as a club, writes Craig Little, there’s an ethic and a grit that fortifies their talent. Netball legend Sharni Layton has confirmed her switch to AFLW, signing with Collingwood for the 2019 season. The 46-cap Diamonds legend retired from the game in August, but the two-time Netball World Cup winner is expected to bring invaluable experience despite her relative rookie status in Aussie Rules. Thinking time “Choosing a nursing home is never pleasant or easy. Most often, it is done in a crisis, when emotions are heightened by drama and urgency,” writes Caroline Baum, as part of Guardian Australia’s series about aged care. So what should you look for? According to Susan Jantos, an aged care specialist, isolation and loneliness shorten life span dramatically. “It’s important to choose a place that makes an effort to sustain residents emotionally. That includes cultural factors which preserve a sense of identity, like being able to eat the food you love or a décor that echoes places that mean something to you.” See also Sarah Russell’s article on the worrying over-prescription of psychotropic drugs to aged-care residents. The Go-Betweens have been the frontrunner on Guardian Australia’s Songs of Brisbane poll with their track Streets of Your Town – but in a letter to the editor, Powderfinger’s ex-drummer Jon Coghill is FURIOUS. “You can’t stop listening to independent darlings the Go-Betweens can you? Are you serious? What happened to Savage Garden? Kate Miller-Heidke? The Veronicas? The Bee Gees? And what about Powderfinger?” Nominations have closed and the leaderboard’s gone dark, but you still have time to knock the Gobees off their top spot before the poll closes on Tuesday. A nine-year-old girl has been subjected to an extraordinary bullying campaign by Australian politicians and prominent media commentators, for the offence of refusing to stand for the national anthem in protest at its erasure of Australia’s Indigenous history. As Van Badham writes, “It is beyond gross that the right’s culture war has become so panicky and weak that adults are willing to abuse the power of their platforms to wage war on a single child … Their incessant, yawping demands for ‘free speech’ and ‘individual rights’ fall silent the moment anyone else exercises any. The right aren’t rebels, they’re apologists for privilege, a quality that eternally defines them.” Media roundup Several leading mastheads including the Financial Review are leading with tumult inside the Coalition government, with Barnaby Joyce accusing Malcolm Turnbull and Julie Bishop of leading a guerrilla campaign against Scott Morrison over the issue of Peter Dutton’s referral to the high court. A damning investigation into the culture of the prestigious St Paul’s College at Sydney University has handed down a 132-page report detailing booze and sex parties, reports the Sydney Morning Herald, including 50 recommendations to address what vice-chancellor Michael Spence had called a culture of “deep contempt for women”. And, the Advertiser writes that a new football stadium in Adelaide is under consideration as part of Australia’s bid to host the 2023 women’s World Cup. The South Australian government has confirmed that it is studying the viability of hosting, but hasn’t confirmed whether that includes plans for a new stadium. Coming up The financial services royal commission continues its hearings into the insurance industry. The official announcement of the winner of the Wagga Wagga byelection will take place this morning with likely political fallout for the NSW government.
